THE ROOTS OF WEIGHT
Have you lost weight, only to gain it right back? Do you eat when you’re not hungry?

results.description:
We learn through doing. Sometimes that means failing. Some of our greatest lessons come from learning what not to do or failing to deliver something important. This is in line with the motto "Fail Fast" which we hear often.

How do we, as agilists, build organizations that embrace the whole of failure as a way of learning? What does it take to allow the team and people to fail, with clear feedback that supports growth and development? How do we make it safe to fail, but still have consequences, because without consequences failure is meaningless?

Bring your collective experience with this, share your challenges and fears, and bring your questions to Ringlers where we get to build our community of practice and learn from each other. Also, we get to eat great food and drink beer!
results.name: Dntn Pub Lnch: Learning through failure - building organizations that embrace it

results.description:
Want to go to ACT-W PDX for free? Sign up to volunteer by June 1 and get a free ticket!

ACT-W conferences run on the energy of our volunteers who care about empowering women and supporters in technology. The ACT-W Portland Conference is an annual 2-day action-packed event where talented women and allies can build skills, grow their community, and accelerate their career path. The conference includes speaking sessions, hands-on workshops, one-on-one coaching sessions, a career fair, and more!

As a volunteer, you’ll be a vital part of the conference and help to create a welcoming and outstanding conference experience for 600 participants from the Portland Area. The volunteer experience is a unique opportunity to participate in the conference activities. Volunteers will be responsible for various conference duties such as staffing the registration/information booth, crowd management, assisting speakers and pre-conference course instructors, and communicating information about the conference. Volunteer shifts are three hours long (though you're welcome to do more!).

People of all genders are welcome to volunteer.

Sign up here: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSenfJ0P8AhIA6317GuFbhjTI3jjg0CLvRuSxc_eZL1mz0i78g/viewform

results.description:
We're running,A City on the Edge a series of 1-hour adventure for 1 through 4 -level characters, at Legends of Gamers.

-----

Often called the “Gateway to Chult”, the exotic city of Port Nyanzaru is built upon a landscape both mystifying and marvelous.

However, the city’s vibrant beauty is overshadowed by a mysterious scourge that plagues all within the land. Can the divergent forces within the city discover the truth before all are overcome by this growing threat?

-----
Seating starts at 5:30 pm with dice up and rolling by 6 pm.

We are capping the RSVPs at 5 to allow for walk-ins; a waitlist will be available. If there are more players than there are available seats then players who RSVP will be seated first, followed by waitlisted players. In the event that we have more players who RSVPed than we have available seats, players who are not seated will be given first priority at the next session they attend.

The maximum number of players at a legal AL table is 7. Please RSVP so we can try to gauge demand. If you are RSVPing for more than just yourself, leave a comment with the names of your +1's.

We start seating walk-in players 20 minutes after the start time. Players who show up after 5:30 pm will be seated at the DM's discretion, regardless of whether they RSVPed. Please be on time!

## Level 1-4

* This is an adventure for PCs of levels 1 through 4. If you do not have a character of the appropriate level, we will have pregenerated characters and logsheets available. NOTE: Make sure that your characters are up-to-date! If your PC is not finished when play begins, you will have to use another legal character.

* You cannot run this adventure more than once unless you use a different character; for more information, see page 2 of the Adventurers League FAQ, available at http://www.dmsguild.com/product/199562/DD-Adventurers-League-FAQ&affiliate_id=925821

* In order to get started on time and keep the game going, you will not be allowed to modify the pregenerated characters before or during the game. You can customize or rebuild your PC characters after the session; for more information, see page 5 of the Adventurers League Player Guide (v6), available at http://www.dmsguild.com/product/208178/DD-Adventurers-League-Players-Pack?&affiliate_id=925821.
results.name: Tualatin - City on the Edge at Legends of Gamers (Lvls 1-4)

results.description:
Pedalpalooza is back! YEAH! It's time to have fun on bikes! There are a ton of fun rides posted on http://www.shift2bikes.org and they start now, even before the official Pedalpalooza start date of June 1st! Look on the calendar when you get to that page!

This Meetup is about the main kickoff ride which welcomes all riders and is a great chance to spread the word about any rides you're leading, and learn more about rides you want to attend.

Meet at Seawall Crest Park at 6pm and roll it slow and sassy at 7pm. After about 15 miles of parade style bike fun, we'll convene at a park for hang out time.

For those of you not familiar with the Portland Bicycle community and their many organized rides here are some tips:

1. BRING BEVERAGES, SNACKS, MONEY TO BUY MORE: It is always appropriate to bring snacks and beverages for yourself or to share. People often bring adult beverages and if consumed discretely and in moderation this should not be a problem. However safety should be your top priority so, particularly if you haven't ridden a bicycle for a while, you might want to save the consumption of adult beverages until after the ride is over.

2. HELMET HELMET HELMET: While bicycle riding is generally a safe sport, and safer when you are in a sea of 100+ bicycles which are highly visible to automobiles, an occasional tumble can happen. I cannot emphasize enough that you should ALWAYS WEAR A HELMET! (I took an unexpected fall back in September, on a bicycle path no less, and I am extremely glad I was wearing a helmet at the time. If anyone wants to see my cracked helmet, just ask!) Many people in the Portland Bicycle Community do not wear helmets and as adults they can make that choice, but please don't be one of them. You can replace your helmet, you can't replace your brain.

3. DRESS FOR THE WEATHER: Wear layers that you can put on or take off as needed. Have something water proof or water resistant for your outer layer. The ride goes rain or shine. TIP: Throw a few plastic trash bags in you back pack - these can be used as rain ponchos and to keep gear dry.

4. LIGHTS LIGHTS LIGHTS!: I put 9pm as the end time - but it could end sooner. However just plan that you might be out past dark and have a front and back light on your bicycle. The more lights the better.

I have these bicycle LED lights on my bicycle wheels and I am very happy with them: "YYGIFT Waterproof 20 LED Bicycle Wheel Light String Safety Cool Bike Wheel Light for Night Safe Cycling - Working with 3AA Batteries" You will find these on Amazon for $9.49 a strand (you need at least two strands - one for each wheel, but buy three so you have a spare.) Shipping is free on this items - with or without Amazon prime! (Note: they are made for a smaller children's bicycle wheel so there will be a small gap of a few inches but this is actually a good thing as it gives you a space where you can put your lock without touching the delicate wire.)

5. LOCK LOCK LOCK: Yes bicycle theft is a chronic problem in PDX. Even locked bicycles are at risk, but a lock is better than nothing. So get the best lock you can afford.

6. EXTRAS: Also a good idea to carry extra air tubes that fit your bicycle and a pump to inflate. Bring tools if you have them, but there is usually some seasoned bicycle rider on these rides who will help you if you get a flat tire. Also, if you are a member of AAA, in Oregon and Idaho, AAA offers the extra service of rescuing bicycle riders in distress. I'm not sure if that means they will change your tire, but they will at least come and get you.

7: CAMERA: There are usually good photo opportunities on these rides. Take pictures and post your best shots here on this meetup so we can share your experience!
results.name: Pedalpalooza Kickoff Ride! Friday June 1st!

First Friday is the east side's monthly art gallery event. We'll meet in the Gallery @ the Jupiter Hotel (note NEW STARTING location this time) and head out at 6:30 to other galleries in the inner east side within walking distance. The galleries on the east side are more geographically spread out than those in the Pearl for First Thursday, so dress in comfortable shoes and for the weather. You can leave the walk early at any time.

Gallery List (see photo for map) Approximately 3.3 miles walking but actual route may vary from map

Start - 1 - Jupiter Hotel Gallery 800 E Burnside St
2 - Black Box Gallery 811 E Burnside St, Suite 212 (second floor)
3 - Eutectic Gallery 1930 NE Oregon St (people who would like to have a shorter route can skip #3 through #5 and go to #6)
4 - True Measure Gallery 3022 E Burnside St
5 - Wolff Gallery 2804 SE Ankeny St
6 - AFRU Gallery 534 SE Oak St
7 - Stephanie Chefas Projects 305 SE 3rd Ave Suite 202 (second floor)

• What to bring
Rain gear, comfortable walking shoes, consider flashlight/high-visibility clothes for walking at night.

Disclaimer: I'm a volunteer and assume no liability for anyone's personal safety on this trip. Being alert to traffic is key!

Please note that there is a $5 cover charge and a "No outside food or drink" policy. They do have a nice menu of soups and sandwiches and offer plenty of snacks and drinks including a couple of beers and hard cider on tap.

We'll have plenty of games there given the great library. I'll certainly be bringing a few games I wouldn't mind getting to the table and encourage anyone else to bring games as well if you'd like. Typically early arrivals would play a shorter filler game and we'd try to get the longer euros started shortly after 7pm or so.

Are you interested in using empathy, mindfulness, and transparency to build community, navigate relationships, and deepen your self-connection? We teach a practice called Non-Violent Communication (NVC) designed for the pursuit of peace both internally and in the world, and we would be delighted to share what we know!

These events are offered 4-6 times a year, are free (donations gladly accepted), and provide experiences and explanations designed to inspire you to what is possible should you decide to make NVC a part of your life! We will meet together for 3 hours in SE Portland. For more information go to http://rosecitynvc.org/free-introduction-to-nvc/

For those of us who enjoy singing, dancing, socializing and good food and drinks all at the same location, Suki's Bar & Grill has all of that on Friday nights!

Karaoke starts at 7pm and goes till closing at 2am, with the Asian Fusion and American food menu till midnight and a full bar till closing!

There's a parking lot off Barbur & Sheridan, and some street parking on Caruthers, but it fills up fast so show up early if you're driving!

Although karaoke starts at 7pm, I'll be there at 6:45 to get a table for us.

Please RSVP before 6pm Friday, so I know how many tables to reserve!

Our table(s) will have a "FOR RENT: MEETUP" sign on the end. It seems that a "For Rent" sign is a welcome sight for many of us during the past several years! :)

Suki's Bar & Grill is just south of downtown at 2401 SW 4th Avenue near Caruthers St (just south of the I-405 Freeway).

I look forward to another Awesome Friday night!

--Cliff H

Planet gongs are powerful tools of transformation and will leave you feeling tuned and refreshed, connected with your intuitive personal power.

The 90-minute event includes a brief discussion the gongs, a 60-minute gong bath meditation, followed by sweets and community.

Benefits of a Gong Bath:

Promotes relaxation and stress relief
Restores vibrational balance and mind-body harmony
Stimulates immune system and glandular functioning

results.description:
CHAKRADANCE™ is a well-being movement practice. It uses spontaneous dance, to specific chakra-resonant music, for the purpose of healing and re-tuning your whole energy system.

The purpose of Chakradance is simple, if ambitious: to help you to more fully embody your soul.

At the heart of Chakradance is the music. For all of us, the seven major chakras are the energetic gateways through which body, mind and spirit come together, literally embodying the soul.

In Chakradance classes and courses, each of these seven chakras has its own unique body of wonderfully danceable music, resonating to its own specific vibrational frequencies.

On one level, Chakradance can be experienced as a joyful affirmation of who you truly are. Using spontaneous dance, creativity and your imagination, it leads to an awakening, a discovery of your true self.

But at a deeper level, Chakradance is also about healing and balance. By surrendering to the music of each chakra, we dance from the inside out and find ourselves awakening and healing ancient hurts; expressing – often for the first time – long-blocked emotions; and opening ourselves up to levels of spiritual connection higher than we ever thought possible.

This is what we mean when we describe Chakradance™ as “rhythm for your soul”. Think of it as a 'dynamic moving meditation to music'... or as 'the musical sister of yoga' (without the set-piece poses or asanas).

There is no right or wrong way to move your body. It’s a journey of self-discovery. Each chakra is explored through specific music, guided imagery and your own free, improvised dance, done in a candle-lit space with your eyes softly closed. This begins to activate inner experiences.

Chakradance puts you in touch with the sacred within yourself. It helps you re-connect with your own soul, unique and beautiful. Dancing the seven chakras is like dancing into seven different worlds, seven different facets of your whole self, each with their own lessons, meanings and stories. As a practice, it helps you to feel more balanced, more joyful, and to radiate your own true colors out into the world.

WHAT TO BRING
yoga mat or blanket
water bottle
wrap/socks if you get cold
results.how_to_find_us: We're over by the red Coffee Barn near Walgreen's

results.description:
Karen Lovely shot onto the blues scene out of the Pacific Northwest like Stack O' Lee's .44 placing 2nd at the 2010 International Blues Challenge followed by three 2011 Blues Music Award Nominations for BEST CONTEMPORARY BLUES FEMALE ARTIST, BEST CONTEMPORARY BLUES ALBUM and BEST SONG for her sophomore release STILL THE RAIN.

Known for her passionate, driven performances, this powerhouse vocalist delivers a blistering mix of contemporary & old school blues. Lovely's standout performances have garnered awards and critical acclaim at festivals and venues throughout the US, Canada and Europe.

With the release of her 3rd studio album TEN MILES OF BAD ROAD, produced by Grammy winner Tony Braunagel, Lovely established herself as a singer/songwriter with a style uniquely her own, receiving nominations for the prestigious 2016 Blues Music Award for "Best Contemporary Blues Female Artist" and 2016 BluesBlast Award for "Best Female Artist". She also won a 2015 Blues411 "Jimi" Award for "Best Contemporary Blues Female Artist" and the album was selected by Downbeat Magazine as one of the Best Albums of 2016.

Her albums have topped the national blues and roots charts and made the Top 10 favorite artist list for dozens of nationally syndicated radio stations. Lovely is a two time “#1 Pick to Click” artist on XM Radio Bluesville and was selected several times as a Featured Blues Artist by KKJZ FM in Los Angeles.

Lovely's newest release, FISH OUTTA WATER debuted at #13 on the Billboard Top 100 Blues Album chart, has been #1 on the RMR state chart for 3 months, hit #1 on the RMR Top 50 Contemporary Blues Singles chart, #4 on the RMR Top 50 Contemporary Blues Album chart, #4 on the RMR Top 50 Blues Album chart and is currently #4 on the Living Blues Top 50 chart. DownBeat Editor's Pick - the magazine calls Fish Outta Water "fantastic". more info

Tickets: $7 at door.

results.description:
UPDATE: I did this hike on Memorial Day. I am making microspikes or crampons as well as waterproof hiking boots a requirement. Forget the snow shoes.

PLEASE READ THE DESCRIPTION OF THIS HIKE BEFORE SIGNING UP.

Difficulty: DIFFICULT

Pace: 2.5 m.p.h.

Distance: 8 miles out and back

Elevation gain: 2570 feet

High Point: 7215 feet.

Permits drivers: Northwest forest pass.

We will be traversing through deep snow on this hike.

Required gear: waterproof hiking boots, microspikes or crampons.

Recommended gear: Gaitors , hiking poles, rain gear weather permitting.

10 Essentials.

Olallie Butte is the third highest peak in Northwest Oregon. It stands between Mount Jefferson and Mount Hood and is surrounded by numerous lakes.
results.how_to_find_us: I drive a black Jeep Wrangler and will park Insight of the front doors at REI
results.name: Olallie Butte Scramble To The Summit.

results.description:
Distance: 16 miles
Elevation Gain: 2600 +
Difficulty: Difficult due to distance
Time on trail: All Day Long... thank goodness! ;)

We will carpool from Salmon Creek Park and Ride. it is a 200 mile round trip. Please be prepared to contribute $15 for drivers if you are carpooling.

I have skirted all around this rugged peak in the St Helen's Monument area but now is the time to make a push for it. The snow is receding quickly, but I anticipate we may cross some remaining snow fields so I am going to recommend bringing traction devices and trekking poles.

We will make this trek taking the longer route from Johnston Ridge... and will have natures beauty as nearly every turn. It will be a lot of up and down... but then a steady climb the last few miles for a total of about 16 miles and 2600 ft elevation gain. This is an in and out hike.... but there is enough beauty to last the entire day!

Those of you that hike with me know that I am a slower and steady hiker. I stop to take pictures as one should on a hike of this nature. Our moving pace will average close to 2.5... a bit slower on the uphill a bit faster downhill. ;)

There is always a chance that we might run into more snow than anticipated and will have to stop short of the goal... but the journey will be the prize in any case.

What to bring:
Ten Essentials
Traction Devices
Trekking Poles
At least 3 liters of water
Sunscreen
Wind / Rain shell
Food
A determination to have a great time!
results.name: Mt Margaret from Johnston Ridge

results.description:
No Thursday hike this week… Since Saturday is a free parking day for Washington State Parks, I took the day off from Delta!

While no technical climbing skills are required, please note that the second part of this hike will involve a brief, hands-over-feet scramble to the top of Horsethief Butte. But first, we’ll catch the tail-end of low altitude wildflower season with a 7 mile loop through scenic Dalles Mountain Ranch!

*Scrambling photo of Katya and me from my Instagram*

Difficulty: Easy, possibly moderate for Dalles Mountain;
Moderate for scrambling up Horsethief Butte

Hiking distance: About 9 miles total, 7 of which are easy wildflower hiking

Elevation gain: 1310 feet for Dalles Mountain, plus 250 feet of easy scrambling for Horsethief Butte

Total time: Let’s try to get back by 4

Permits: No Discover Passes required for this Saturday

Gas: 174 mile RT drive, so $17 suggested to drivers for gas, unless drivers determine otherwise

Dogs: Not on this one, due to the Horsethief Butte section

The Dalles Mountain Ranch trail network is a real treat, and props to NW Wilderness leader Barbara for bringing this area to my attention last year. In addition to the remaining lupine and balsamroot blooms, we’ll hike past streams, rocky outcroppings, ranch buildings, heart-filling views of the Gorge, and even a waterfall.

We won’t stop for lunch, though, until the final section of our event. Just south of Dalles Mountain Ranch are the climbing crags of Horsethief Bluff, a popular spot for climbing instructors to test their students’ verticals skills. We’ll find a short, moderate scrambling route through the rocks to hit the high point for our lunch, served with a sweet view of the eastern Columbia River Gorge.

Here is more information about this area: https://www.wta.org/go-hiking/hikes/columbia-hills-state-park

My preferred hiking style is brisk (3-3.5 mph when not running), but let’s see how it goes. We’ll enjoy short breaks as needed for snacks, photos, and viewpoints. There is no such thing as too many photo opps.

Bring: Lunch, sturdy shoes or boots, water, snacks, warm layers, a rain jacket, and a camera

It is also recommended that hikers always carry the Ten Essentials:
1. Navigation (map, compass, and an awareness of our route)
2. Sun protection (sunglasses and sunscreen)
3. Insulation (extra clothing)
4. Illumination (headlamp/flashlight and extra batteries)
5. First-aid supplies
6. Fire (waterproof matches/lighter/candles)
7. Knife/tools
8. Nutrition (extra food)
9. Hydration (extra water)
10. Emergency whistle and general preparedness in the event that you become separated from our group and/or have to spend the night in the wild.

PARTICIPATE AT YOUR OWN RISK; NW Wilderness Group organizers are volunteers. We come prepared to lead you on a trail or off trail hike but assume no liability for your safety getting to or from the trail-head or on the hike. In case of accident, illness, or other incapacity, hikers must pay for their own medical and/or evacuation expenses, whether or not the hiker has specifically authorized them.
results.how_to_find_us: Green Jeep Wrangler, brown soft top (SE corner of parking garage, by the elevator)
results.name: Dalles Mountain Ranch- Horsethief Butte hike/scramble

Location: Mt St helens Area

Hey guys. So every year over the last 25 years we volunteer to help a big free fishing weekend out at Hagg Lake. Its run by a non profit called, "I'm Hooked" and they setup fishing stations as well as provide boat rides for kids and families. Started out helping at need kids and moved to showing all types of families the joy of fishing. We serve about[masked] people a day and send them out in boats for 1 1/2 hour boat rides and fishing. Lot of fun.
Need volunteers for directing people, setting up fishing equipment, etc.
Just show up.
Fun starts around 6 or so for setup. Breakfast and lunch are included at no cost. Some people bring a tent and sleep out Friday night and saturday night. No parking cost either.
All at Boat Ramp C. Far end of the lake.

results.description:
• What we'll do
There’s something for absolutely everyone on this fun-filled day downtown and on Lake River. Breakfast, paddling, obstacle course, live music, beer & wine garden, BIG games and a Totally Awesome Scavenger Challenge!

7:00AM Breakfast @ Port of Ridgefield Waterfront

7:00AM Guided Birding Tour @ Waterfront

8:00AM-4:30PM Paddler’s Village Opens @ Waterfront (NO entrance fee)
Fun-filled festival atmosphere – Celebrate the excitement of outdoor recreation by visiting vendor booths, enjoying the Carty Lake interpretive walk, being creative with hands-on activities, enjoying an outdoor massage, listening to live marimba music, enjoying a cold beer and a refreshing lunch, and MORE!

9:00AM @ Waterfront
Welcome Ceremony with Chinook Drumming and Blessing

9:00AM – 3:00PM Farmer’s Market @ Overlook Park in Downtown Ridgefield

9:00-4:00PM Ridgefield Trolley Rides shuttle between Overlook Park and the waterfront activities. Sponsored by Port of Ridgefield.

9:30-3:00PM Obstacle Course @ Waterfront (FREE)
Hilarious thrills, magnificent spills and larger-than-life obstacles combine to make an epic, painfully funny experience. Jump, balance and crawl through this kid friendly course. Test yourself with the archery challenge. No set start time. No timer. Become an obstacle course hero! SPONSORED BY CLIFF SALLEE, UNLEASHED FITNESS NW

9:30AM-2:00PM Totally Awesome Scavenger Challenge
Turn Ridgefield into a giant game board that will provide a sightseeing tour of downtown Ridgefield and the waterfront. As an individual, with a buddy, or as a team, you decipher clues to find well-known locations and overlooked gems in the area while completing fun and easy challenges. All participants who complete the challenge receive prizes. Begin at the waterfront or at Overlook Park. SPONSORED BY RIDGEFIELD FIRST SATURDAY

9:30AM Interpretive Paddle @ Waterfront
Flotilla of kayaks, big canoes and stand-up paddleboards launch for a 5 mile, two-hour interpretive tour – along Lake River, through the Ridgefield National Wildlife Refuge and to the confluence with the Columbia River and returning to the launch site. Registration is required for this paddle in advance on Eventbrite or on the day of the event for a $5 event fee or $20 for groups up to 6 members. The event fee does not include a rental. You can bring a boat or rent on location from Ridgefield/Alder Creek Kayak. RESERVE in advance at Ridgefield/Alder Creek Kayak.

11:00AM Beer Garden Opens @ Waterfront

11:30AM Live Music with ChicaMarimba @ Waterfront

1:30PM Recreational Paddle @ Waterfront
Enjoy a relaxing paddle with a kayak, canoe or stand-up paddleboard. Register and sponsored by Ridgefield/Alder Creek Kayak.

2:00PM Carty Lake Interpretive Walk @ Waterfront/Ridgefield National Wildlife Refuge

4:30PM Closing Ceremony @ Waterfront
Enjoy bonfire with s’mores!

• What to bring
If you want to do the paddle, you'll need to reserve kayaks in advance. You will be responsible for all your own arrangements and payments.
You are welcome to participate in some or all activities. You don't have to be into kayaking to have a great time!

• Important to know
I'm planning to be there for most of the event but may not be kayaking - there are lots of other things to do. Post in the discussion what you're interested in, and we can group up.
Kayaks will book up soon, so if you want to kayak and need a loaner, register soon!

Here is the event page, with links to kayak rentals and more info.
https://ridgefieldwa.us/event/big-paddle/
results.name: Enjoy festivities and water activities at Ridgefield Big Paddle

results.description:
Bells Mountain Hike

Start point: Moulton Falls Upper TrailheadEnd point: Cedar Creek BridgeTrail Log:Hike Type: In and out Distance: 15.6 milesElevation gain: 3040 feet

The Bells Mountain Trail has been designated part of a 31-mile “National Recreation Trail” which begins at the Hantwick Road Trailhead and ends at the Bluff Mountain Trailhead. This moniker is slightly ironic as there is no trail in our area that takes in so many clearcuts and brand-new logging roads; in this respect, and because of destructive ATV incursions, it has been declared an “endangered” trail by the Washington Trails Association. The trail was constructed by the Chinook Trail Association, using a substantial grant, which has included it in their vision for a 300-mile loop trail around the Columbia Gorge. From the clearcuts, there are great views on a fine day of the Dole Valley, back to Yacolt, Kloochman Butte, Larch Mountain, Silver Star Mountain, Mount Saint Helens, and Mount Adams. Wildflowers will be out in the spring and the second half of the hike runs along quiet Cedar Creek.

A car shuttle is possible in the spring and summer when the road to Cold Creek Trailhead is open.

WARNING: Pay attention to temporary signs posted at the trailheads and junctions. There is frequent logging activity along this trail. The trail may be closed at some points, entirely closed, or closed on weekdays.

You can visit both Moulton Falls and Yacolt Falls before crossing the East Fork on the high bridge and heading down the East Fork Lewis River Greenway on the “baby stroller” trail on the old railroad grade. To reach the bridge from the Moulton Falls Trailhead, walk on the path next to the highway and then cut in past a shed and traverse up the hill to the bridge. From the Moulton Falls Upper Trailhead, which has many more parking spaces, drop in Douglas-fir woods with a sword fern, salal, Oregon grape, and salmonberry understory to a junction. Go left here and head up to cross the East Fork High Bridge and get a bird’s eye view of the gorge on both sides.

Keep straight on the wide, flat railroad grade to pass another picnic area down to the right. Get a view through the alders and cedars to little Moulton Falls pushing through its cleft. Pass under a rock face and then through an alley of red alder. Drop gently to a footbridge and, a few yards later, come to the Moulton Falls-Bells Mountain Trail Junction, with its kiosk and signboard indicating 7.2 miles to Cold Creek.

Go left here, rise up the slopes of Bells Mountain, and switchback in mossy Douglas-fir, big-leaf maple, and alder woods with a sword fern carpet. Then the trail makes a descending traverse and crosses a footbridge above a small waterfall. Ascend in three switchbacks and come to the 0.5 mile marker (You will see these DNR half-mile posts the length of the hike). Keep left at a junction with a trail that leads down to a clearcut. Cross a footbridge at a spring sprouting skunk-cabbage and keep rising to pass your first clearcut of the day. There’s a view back down the Dole Valley to Yacolt from here. Reenter a stand of forest left along a creek and then enter a replanted clearcut, crossing the end of a logging spur. Enter leafy woods again, cross a creek and come to another clearcut (It should be said that the clearcuts leaf out with lush shrubbery and blooms in the spring and early summer, making the trip a little more palatable). Navigate the slope, cross another forested creek drainage, and meet a large clearcut, hike across it, and then enter a Douglas-fir plantation. Cross a bulrush-hemmed stream at the 2.5 mile marker and make a gentle descent to a logging road. Go right for 15 yards and resume the trail, which drops alongside and alder-shaded creek. Join an old road bed and descend to switchback down to a sturdy footbridge over the creek which runs between Bells and Spotted Deer Mountains.

The trail rises in mossy secondary forest, crossing above a spring in an alder-shaded bowl. Enter a recent clearcut with a view back to Bells Mountain. Cross a newly decommissioned logging road and pass through two forested creek corridors at Milepost 4.0 before hitting clearcut slopes again. The trail reaches a road. Here you need to head 200 yards up to the left before finding the resumption of the path. Hike across another wide swath of clearcut slope with views ahead to Silver Star Mountain. Pass through a tree island and reach a road. Go right 15 yards and find the trail one more time. Alternate more clearcut and forested corridors before reaching a clearcut slope with a direct view to Larch Mountain. The trail has been rerouted down the left side of this cut and then angles down to cross an abandoned ATV track that parallels Cedar Creek.

The rest of the hike heads up the creek, sometimes crossing or using the ATV track. Posts have been set to prevent ATVs from taking the foot trail. The lush woods along the creek are comprised of Douglas-fir, western hemlock, western red-cedar, red alder, and big-leaf maple interspersed with skunk-cabbage bogs. Footbridges cross the tributaries to Cedar Creek. Where the ATV track fords Cedar Creek, head up a sword fern slope, and then traverse down to creek level. The trail rises again in mossy woods of older Douglas-fir, cedar, and hemlock. Drop to a boggy area of devil’s club, skunk-cabbage, and salmonberry. At about Milepost 7.0, get views of the Cold Creek Day-use Area across Cedar Creek. Switchback down from the edge of a clearcut, cross a creek, and hike on the level to the large “continental bridge” over Cedar Creek to reach the Cedar Creek Bridge.

This is a good turn around point. To the right is a small viewing platform at a pretty scene: tall conifers shade a short drop in the cold, clear waters of the creek and you might observe a dipper bobbing for insects in the spate. From the junction, the Bells Mountain Trail continues another 0.6 miles to its junction with the Tarbell Trail. If you are doing a car shuttle, it’s 0.2 miles on a universal trail to the Cold Creek Day-use Area.
results.name: Bells Mt Hike

results.description: HK B2 Jun 02 (Sat) Paradise Park (loop from Timberline Lodge) (W) Bill Stein, hike leader. Route changed due to reports of significant blowdown on the trail from Hwy 26; we will still need to get around at least one downed tree blocking the trail on a steep slope. Wilderness -- Limited 12. Paradise Park is best known for its wildflower displays in July and August, but this hike is a classic mountain trek on many levels. In addition to the mountain vistas and wildflowers, the route passes several waterfalls, deep canyons, and offers unique views of the high country south and west of Mount Hood. 12.1 mi., 2300 Ft., Drive 102, Clackamas P&R Garage 7:30 a.m. (WF,AR,MH,WO) MU
results.name: Paradise Park (loop from Timberline Lodge) - Hike

results.description:
Dragon boat team "Dragon Fuel" is looking for Men and Women paddlers to add to the team. We want paddlers 18 and up that want to come to practice regularly. We are a fun competitive mixed team that welcomes people of all backgrounds and fitness levels. Join us for a practice on the Willamette River.

See the city skyline from the water, and feel the power of up to 20 paddlers in sync as we surge under the Tillicum bridge. We practice year-round, rain or shine! We love to incorporate fitness and healthy living into our every day lives and what better way to have fun exercising than to paddle as a team. Come join us anyone can do it! Try it once you'll love it! We meet behind Kimpton River Place Hotel, on the water side, 1510 SW Harbor Way, Portland, OR 97201

1) No experience required we will train you!
2) life jacket and paddles supplied for you to use Free by the club Dragon Sports USA
3) we meet 3 times a week
Monday & Wednesday 7:10 PM warm up 7:30-8:30 PM on the water Saturday 7:40 warm up 8-9 AM on the water
4) 3 local races and 2 traveling races
5) Your first 3 practices are free- just let us know you are coming!

What to bring:
• Dress in workout attire and prepare to get wet.
• Please bring water.

Important to know:
*We use Meetup to Recruit for new members so existing team members will not show up on the "going" list
• Leave personal belongings at home or in your car. Storage space is little to none.
• Space on the boat is limited- RSVP so we can plan ahead
results.how_to_find_us: Please wait by the drinking fountain at the stairs just before you go down to the board walk. Brandy Jackson or a Dragon Fuel member will get you.
results.name: Fun on the water_Team Dragon Fuel

group.name: Have fun on the water dragon boating_Team Dragon Fuel

results.description:
Hiking Distance: ~ 10 to 12 Miles
Pace: 2-3 mph
RSVPs Open Thursday 5/31 @ 7:30PM

Rating: Long Distance but on a gravel road that follows the Deschutes River South to the town of Dant & possibly further. MODERATE

Hiking Time: 6 Hours.

# of Hiker's: 8 ( but I may add more)

The plan is to travel out and over Hood via Hwy 26 then through Maupin as we descend into the Deschutes Canyon. Crossing the river we turn South along a well graded gravel road. About 9 miles north, we come to a TH. on the left & a gate across the road.

Traveling South on foot through the Canyons (1,800' high in places), turn around and head back. All while taking in the ever-changing panorama of shadows that play out upon the Canyon walls. Just to repeat, we will follow a gravel road that runs along the Deschutes.

Depending on time, I'm always up for a good foot soak in cool waters.

Driving back towards Maupin we climb out of the Canyon drive North West toward Hood River and dinner at Divots Restaurant.

Weather forecast calls for sun and 80•. Canyon walls may at times provide some shade.

The photo shows the mid point of the hike. You will be down in the bottom of the canyon along the river

Bring:
2.5 liters of water
sunscreen
PLENTY OF SNACKS
Lunch
10 Essentials
Sports Drink/Electrolytes
Hiking Poles (possible off route exploring

It's roughly 200 miles so suggested donation to carpool drivers is $22.00

Estimated return time 9:30PM.

Trailhead meetups:No
Dogs:No

6:30PM reservations for dinner @ Divots Restaurant in Hood River.

On the way out, we will stop at either-or-both; ZigZag Ranger Station & Maupin for restroom breaks.

Also recommend a snack, second breakfast/first lunch at the Maupin stop.

Leaving Promptly at 7:45 AM. If you are late there should be 🍩 donuts involved.
results.how_to_find_us: 1st Floor (we leave at 7:45 so plan on being there by 7:30AM)
results.name: High Desert, Deep Canyons, Flowing Waters

results.description:
Enjoy a walk in the countryside through fields of beautiful and colorful peonies at the award winning Adelman Peony Gardens with 500 varieties in 25 acres. The 5K/10K routes go through the peony fields and display gardens. The 10K walk will also take you on country roads to nearby Sebight Hosta Gardens with several hundred varieties of hostas, ferns and other shade-preferred plants. (LEASHED, sociable dogs are welcomed at both gardens). You will also see such sights as irises in bloom in the Mid-American Garden, a filbert grove, agricultural fields, remnants fo Lake Labish and perhaps Mt.Hood.

Registration for the 10K walk begins at 8AM and ends at 12PM
Registration for the 5K walk begins at 8AM and ends at 1PM
Both walks are scheduled to end by 3PM
Walk is free, $3 for AVA credit walkers. Water & restrooms available at start of walk and at check point. friendly dogs welcome at both gardens. lease laws and clean up apply.

Directions: 5700 Brooklake Road. From North I-5: exit 263

Contact Don Reed (541)[masked] [masked] for further information.
results.name: Brooks Peonies, Hostas and More 5k/10k

results.description:
We're going to try this again. We'll be taking a group out to Salmon Slab. Salmon slab is a climbing area in Zigzag near Mt. Hood. Salmon Slab is a pretty low key climbing area. It has five routes on it that range from 5.5 to 5.9. None of the routes are terribly long and there is good visibility of the climber from the ground so we should have fun. This is a great opportunity for people who have never climbed outdoors before.

What you'll need
Shoes
Harness
Helmet
Belay device
Locking carabiner
Food and water

If you have a rope that would be great, too, but not necessary.

Also, please be aware that if there are no clouds the sun will be beating the heck out of us come noon so sun screen and fluids are a good idea, too.

For those of you who go to Planet Granite you're likely used to using GriGris. I'm not sure how many, if any, we will have. They have an introduction to climbing class at Portland Rock Gym where they teach you to use an ATC, which is less expensive than a GriGri. In any event, you should be comfortable with top rope belaying before signing up for this even.

I also want to emphasize that those of us organizing this are not professional climbers. We just really like it and also like introducing people to it. Having said that, I can't stress enough the benefit of hiring a professional to teach you things. We will do everything we can to keep people safe but please be aware that rock climbing is an inherently dangerous sport and there is always a risk associated with it. I'd like everyone to be mindful of this when signing up. We will have a form for you to sign on the day of acknowledging this.
results.how_to_find_us: Will be at the North East corner
results.name: Outdoor climbing for newbies

results.description:
This is not a RLAG-hosted ride but a biking event open to the public. We are posting the event on our calendar to provide a means for women to express their interest in attending (RSVP) and connect with other RLAG members who are riding. Use the comments section below to arrange carpools, meeting times, questions, and share what distance you plan to do, etc.

No-host event - We invite all interested girlfriends to RSVP here but you MUST also register at the official Pioneer Century website: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/2018-pioneer-century-tickets-40174434816.

The Pioneer Century is named to reflect the history of the Champoeg, Canby, and Molalla areas. The ride starts from the Clackamas County Fairgrounds – 694 NE 4th Avenue, Canby, Oregon. Rich farmland and timber brought the pioneers to this area and this same beauty draws cyclists today. The Pioneer Century offers great routes whether you seek a social ride or personal best. SAVE $5 on your Pioneer Century registration:
1. Go to registration page: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/2018-pioneer-century-tickets-40174434816
2. Click "Tickets" button
3. Select "PWTC & Affiliate Clubs"
4. Complete form and select RLAG for Club Affiliation field
5. Member ID = RLAG2018
6. Post a comment on this Meetup page to share which distance you plan ride, etc. and connect with girlfriends who are doing the same!
results.name: EVENT: Pioneer Century (8, 34, 62 100 or 104 miles)

results.description:
Meet at 8:15 for group warm up. We will be off the water by 9:30.

Every Saturday we welcome everyone to come join us on Vancouver Lake. Dragon boating is easy to learn, hard to master and and a lot of fun. You will get a workout. Dress to get splashed and bring a bottle of water. We provide the boats, paddles, life jackets and the coaching. We are 5 minutes from downtown Vancouver and have members from as far away as Yacolt and Lake Oswego. It's worth the trip. The group is diverse and welcoming. Ages 16 to 80+. No experience is necessary. Hope to see you out soon!
results.how_to_find_us: We are on the west side of Vancouver Lake just past the split in the road that goes to Frenchman's Bar or Vancouver Lake Park.  The parking lot is about 200 feet past the split on the right.  Gate is open, come on in!

results.description:
Moderate- challenging 8 miles with 2000 elevation. Pace 2 mph. I like to take time for pictures and don't like to rush. (If you like to go fast, this is not the hike for you.) I also do ask that the group says together.

Please bring plenty of water, snacks, proper shoes, microspikes (just in case, though I read there shouldn't be any more snow.) Trekking poles and a good attitude are always a plus too. The road to the trail head has been fine in the past for sedans, however, just to be on a safe side, if you have an SUV and would like to drive, that would be appreciated. Donations to drivers $10. We will leave from Gateway promptly at 8:15am.
Our return time should fall around 5pm and we may stop for a snack after if the group wants to.

Silver Star is located in the Gifford Pinchot National Park in Washington. On a clear day, we'll be able to see Mount Adams, Mount Hood, Mount Rainier and Mount St. Helens.

http://www.nwhiker.com/GPNFHike51.html

Please note that we are volunteers and are not responsible for your safety and well-being.

results.description:
Looking for a refreshing weekend at the coast? Join us for a hike of the Nehalem Loop (5.2 miles) along the beach. This trail passes grassy dunes, sea lions and sitka spruce.

If weather is sunny, bring a tent and camp overnight at Nehalem Bay State Park. Each of our three sites has a barbeque pit and space for up to two cars and eight campers. Saturday is Free Fishing Day, so optionally gather clams or throw out a crab ring at low tide on Saturday evening (6 PM).

To RSVP, begin by creating a profile and apply (https://beta.mazamas.org/activity/instance/2062/). Feel free to add yourself here on meetup as a reminder, but you must be an accepted registrant on mazamas.org to attend. Again, only fully registered applicants may join.

Meet at Hillsboro REI 9:00am to carpool. RSVP with $10 camping fee on mazamas.org. Hike is 5.2 miles, 25'. 170 miles RT from Portland.

Mazamas is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit based in Portland, operating under special agreement with the USFS and Oregon State Parks. We promote mountaineering education and outdoor conservation. Follow our activities here and at mazamas.org.

Participants must be ready for coastal spring conditions, windstorms and sand. If new to AYM trips, review our hiking rules. Please consult the winter checklist to ensure you have adequate gear.

Your profile is an important part of your RSVP. It gives co-adventurers a first impression and builds trust. To participate, your profile must include a friendly and professional looking photo and intro.

As outdoor stewards, the Mazamas actively encourage participants to carpool and minimize our footprint. Plus it’s a great way to meet other participants on your adventure! Carpools are self-selected during sign-in, allowing individuals to choose a driver they perceive is safe and responsible.

Our events are alcohol, smoking, and drug free. Pets are only allowed if the leader of has specifically designated the event as pet-friendly. Adventurous Young Mazamas (AYM) offers outdoor activities year-round targeted to younger adults in their 20s & 30s. All activities are open to everyone 18 and over who can safely participate in our events.

Our events have nominal fees applied to the trip or donated to Mazamas for general expenses. Leaders are volunteers and receive no portion of event fees. We carpool to most outdoor events and expect passengers to contribute to the cost of transportation, permits and any parking passes. Standard Mazamas rate is 10 cents/mile/person, though contributions are at the discretion of drivers.

All AYM leaders have First Aid training and are vetted by our committee for their skills and experience. Participants must follow leader instructions in order to protect group safety. Leaders reserve the right to only include participants who are adequately prepared, amicable and safe.

Please treat other participants with respect and consideration. Many of our events have more people wishing to participate than we can accommodate. Only RSVP yes if you are committed to attending.

Meetup provides a platform for people to become friends through shared interests and activities. Part of building trust and friendship starts with using an identifiable profile photo of yourself, so people know who you are and we can find each other - especially when meeting the first time.

This is a group to meet friends for outdoor adventures, not a dating site. To join, others must feel comfortable and safe with you. On social media, please follow us on Facebook and Instagram (aympdx) where you can also see many pictures from our events.
results.name: Nehalem Beach Campout

results.description:
Let's meet at the first parking area off of Germantown Road, coming up from highway 30 (see map link below). It's a u-shaped parking area where the end of Leif Erikson connects with Germantown Road.

Here's the loop (starting from the parking lot):

South on Leif Erikson
Right onto Hardesty
Right onto Wildwood
Right onto Canon

Canon trail ends back at the parking lot. The route ends up being about 5.5 miles total, and it's a bit easier than our Pittock run.

Here is a map of the route:

http://www.mappedometer.com/?maproute=291296

Let's head over to the Clearing Cafe near 28th and Thurman afterward. See you there!
results.name: Germantown Loop

results.description:
We changed our name from Buddhist Mindfulness and Meditation to Waking Up Community in NE Portland!

Our new name reflects the nature of our gatherings where we meditate and explore Buddhist concepts from a variety of sources. We are a spiritual circle within Leaven Community and average 10-20 people a week.

Join us Saturday mornings from 9:00 to 10:30am. No prior meditation experience needed, just come as you are and be prepared to learn something new about yourself!

Meditation sessions last 50 minutes and include opportunity for sitting, walking/movement. A group discussion follows on a topic introduced by the week's discussion leader. Afterwards we enjoy refreshments and casual conversations as we get to know one another and deepen relationships.

By coming together each week we strengthen our mindfulness practice, enjoy community, and develop a more mindful outlook with which to live and act in our interconnected world. http://leaven.org

results.description:
Are you frustrated in your life and feel like things just aren't working out?

Do you wish there was an easy button that would make life flow without much effort on your part?

Are you clear to what you want in life?

Or do you feel like the negative boogeyman has hijacked your brain and you can't seem to get unstuck?

Then this workshop is for you!

Luis Navarrete and I will be hosting this truly LIFE CHANGING workshop on the weekend of June 2-3rd.

In this workshop we will help you:

-See that your thoughts are powerful and can be changed into thoughts that serve you and not take away from your life.

-Gain clarity to what you REALLY want and finally put those request into a powerful momentum.

-Get past those negative beliefs that have held you back for so long.

-Fall in love with who you really are and use that new found self love to experience life to its fullest.

-How to use the Law of Attraction with ease, thereby allowing everything that you want to flow to you with ease (yes, it really is easy!).

-And much MUCH more.

As a Certified Happiness Coach, Soul Coach® and author of "Thrive and Shine! How to Find Happiness When Life Falls Apart", I will share with you all that I have learned AND experienced over the years.

I have fallen down (multiple times) and have found the best way out of my rut is to realize that my thoughts are the cause. But they are also my cure.

And when I realized how to use them to my advantage, take responsibility for my life, forgave the past and fell in love with myself, my life truly became MAGICAL!

Luis too overcame a lot of struggles in life and hit rock bottom. He became a Licensed Matrix Energetic's Practitioner and realized his gifts in channeling. He has downloads all the time about how to get past our struggles and I feel OVER THE TOP excited about teaching this workshop with him.

For more information about our workshop and to reserve your spot go to:

www.changeyourlifeworkshops.com.

You can also go to our FB page where we are posting inspiring videos on a regular basis:

https://www.facebook.com/CYLWS/.

This workshop will be 9-5 on both Sat and Sun. It will be fun, interactive and LIFE CHANGING.

I guarantee you will leave feeling inspired and have let go of some baggage that has been holding you back.

Life gets truly fantastic when we say YES to being who we really are.

It really does.
results.name: Change Your Mind, Change Your Life Workshop

results.description:
Bring your four-legged companion and join us on a hike for some fun, exercise, and socialization!

***IMPORTANT***
Please do not use flexi leashes. FIXED leashes 6ft. or shorter are required. You will not be able to join the walk with a flexi leash.

$10 per dog, cash or Venmo.

VENMO OPTION:
Search for "The Balanced Dog" or[masked] to pay via card.

This group was started by our pack leader, Lyndsi. She found that during her training sessions with reactive dogs there weren't enough triggers within the neighborhood to get the dog the exposure, and repetition it needed to effectively reinforce positive social behaviors. She thought it would be great to have everyone come together to help each other!

Pack walk begins with a brief overview of basic desensitization techniques for anyone who needs support or is unsure of what techniques to use for their dog. During this time please maintain 6 ft. from dogs until bandanas are on and we understand each other’s needs. We accept that everyone comes from different backgrounds and different trainers and we encourage you to use techniques that work best for you and your dog. Lyndsi tries to bring new tips each week to ensure that each individual gets the knowledge they need. Please bring your treat pouches and the treats that your dog thinks are the best treats in the whole world!

We use a colored bandana system to create a safe environment for both owners and dogs. Bandanas are provided at the beginning of each walk.

Green= Dogs who are comfortable being greeted by people and other dogs.

Yellow= Dogs who are frightful of people, but comfortable meeting new dogs.

Red= Dogs who are reactive with people and other dogs— so we know to give space.

This is a journey for both you and your dog! We are here to support you so please push through your butterflies and join us, we promise you won’t regret it.

We strive to make this a safe, positive, fun, supportive and educational experience for everyone who comes.

Please message us if you have any questions or concerns and we look forward to seeing you at the next pack walk! Let your journey begin!

IMPORTANT!
AGAIN, No flexi leashes. NONE!

Refund Policy
This is a deeply discounted training class. Please give 24 hours notice if you would like to receive a refund or have your payment credited to another walk. This gives us time to fill your spot. Thank you!
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in the Visitor Center Parking Lot.
results.name: Socialization Pack Walk

results.description:
Historic Willamette was established in 1893 upriver from Oregon City on the west side of the Willamette River. Over the next decade Willamette became the home for hundreds of power plant and mill workers and their families. The need for safe drinking water led to annexation by West Linn in 1916. Today, the historic core of old Willamette features a vibrant concentration of shops, restaurants and other services; and a compact 16 block National Register residential historic district.

We’ll explore the attractive, pedestrian friendly main street and walk through the historic residential area viewing some well-preserved late Victorian and Craftsman architecture. After the tour join us for optional food and beverage in one of the many dining choices along main street.

Easy urban walk of less than 2 miles in about 2 1/2 hours.

The fee for this narrated tour is $15. You may pay by check, cash or credit card at the start of the tour. You may also use PayPal by following this link: http://bit.ly/22q0waD

How to meetup for the museum - this event will require some effort on your part to organize yourself and others from the meetup group. Please follow these steps:

results.description:
Marsha is leading us in learning how to create Vision Boards, sometimes called Dream Boards, a fun tool for self-discovery. These projects can help you uncover ideas or goals and focus on what you want in your life, whether it is a feeling, a destination, a specific project, or an actual material product.

Creating and using vision boards serves several purposes, some of which include helping you to:

* Identify your vision and give it clarity.
* Reinforce your daily affirmations.
* Keep your attention on your intentions.

Vision Boards Help Provide Clarity:

For example, to say “I want a better life” is a fine goal, but have you given serious thought to exactly what that means? Try to envision what your “better life” looks like. For those of us who find that somewhat difficult, making a vision board can be a tremendous help.

In order to create my vision board, I must actively seek images that represent specific details of this wonderful new life. That means narrowing it down to specifics.

For some, a better life might mean having a new car or home.

Others may be seeking a new relationship or improvements in existing relationships.

Doubtless you have heard it said that most of us never get what we want because we don’t know what we want. Making a vision board is a wonderful way to bring clarity to that general desire and turn it into an achievable goal.

• What to bring

* Glue sticks, several. Tape runners or your other favorite adhesive is fine.
* Poster board, artist board, or some other strong surface.
* Cutting tools; scissors, X-acto, etc.
* Images and words that speak to you, bring more than you need!
* Washi tape (optional, but fun)
* Magazines to share with everyone if you have some to spare.

• Important to know

Marsha will be offering some poster board for folks who don't have any. While she's demonstrating how to make Vision Boards on poster board, she will be talking about other options as well.

Some of the text describing Vision Boards was referenced from: https://www.makeavisionboard.com

results.description:
We head to Mary S Young Park for a summer day of running and playing in the Willamette River. This park has something for everyone! The Walk is level, and can vary in length for your doggo's age and health, there is an off-leash play park for high-energy dogs to run, and we'll be stopping by the Willamette to cool off!

The Walk itself is a little over 2 miles, and will take two hours with stops to run and play. Please continue to obey leash rules (both for the group, and the park) while on the trails. There's plenty of opportunity to run off-leash at the park and on the river.

We will be playing at the off-leash park before and after the hike, so please join in!

Our monthly Pack Walks are fun, social, outdoor walks with our dogs between 2-4 miles, in and around the Portland OR metro area. The monthly walk is scheduled the first Saturday, at 10:00, with changing locations.

Who is welcome? Everyone, and every dog is welcome.

My dog is learning social skills, can she come? Yes. Group walks can help your dog learn to socialize as they bond over common goals and release anxiety through exercise. The group is very understanding, and will give your dog all the space she/he needs.

There are shy dogs and very friendly dogs in the group. My dog is an aussie, and he likes to bark to tell me what's happening. Other dogs hang out at the edge of the group and wonder what the fuss is about. Once walking though, all the dogs like to bump shoulders and sniff around together.

What kinds of dogs come? All kinds of dogs and humans enjoy they walks - everything from big, poofy Bernese mountain dogs to little, poofy Pomeranians.
results.name: Monthly Pack Walk - Mary S Young Park

The 4T will be started at the Oregon Zoo/Washington Park Max Station. The four-miles hike, and tram, trolley, and train take between three and four hours to complete. Near the trolley stop, in front of downtown’s Central Library, is the nearby food carts. So let's grab a bite to eat after building up a healthy appetite, so bring some money for lunch.

The hiking section is approximately 4 miles with about 600 feet in elevation gain. The pace will be fast (3 to 3.5 miles an hour), so you should be very comfortable with hiking. Bring water with you.

You can park in the zoo parking lot ($8) or take MAX from another location. I'm parking for free at the Sunset Transit Station and coming over from there.

A Tri-Met all day pass costs $5 and will cover riding the MAX Light Rail (the train) and Portland Street Car (the trolley). If we weren't getting lunch I would say we could do the 2 1/2 hour pass ($2.50), but that's pushing it.

Events start promptly at time indicated. Bring rain gear if it rains.

For more information go to:

results.description:
Dwarves freed from torture and potential Displacer Beast food. Draco and his former Crew Officers captured, then executed by the now-cured Stephen, Duke of Rhoona. The party had found the treasure room that Draco had not, and placed the looting blame upon his head. When offered Draco’s old ship, the Sea Ghost, for sale to the group, the party had plenty of funds to buy the ship from the people of Rhoona and in turn, refilled the coffers for the coming reconstruction and reparation efforts the Duke now is enacting to restore peace among the people and with their former trading partners in Rockhome.

Still, the words that Draco spoke about Arcane Casters working to enslave the non-arcane talented humanoids, and were ‘destroying the World’ did seem like insane dunce-hat-wearing claims, yet there is some thread of what he said that doesn’t quite go away in the backs of your minds...

The news of War in the Westvagainst the Desert Nomads and the Master of Hule, Hosadus, are becoming more frequent in tavern talk as of late. The party, with their new form of transport, and crew provided by Rhoona for a year’s time, will soon be a topic of discussion when next we meet.

total xp gained this session: TBD

New loot:
The sailing ship, DFMS Sea Ghost.
Other items and wealth total TBD.

There is a larger city where uncommon wealth can be found for sale at the major trading port of Akesoli, just a few days of sailing away...

No need to bring your own games! They have a wall full of games from which to choose. See the Library below along with the menu.

Another Meetup group which I lead called PDX Middleweight Games will be there at the same time. (So don't worry if this one only shows 2 or 3 RSVPs - An RSVP would encourage more Gaymers to also RSVP.) Wow, this is going to be fun! I want be worn out from a lot of Catan, Ticket to Ride, Splendor, or whatever! We generally are at the tables toward the back. I wear suspenders!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This time we'll be playing at the Game Knight Lounge, the recently opened board game pub on N Williams. They have a library of over 450 games to choose from plus food and drinks!

You can find their library here ---> http://pdxgameknight.com/library/

You can find their menu here ---> http://pdxgameknight.com/menu/

These roving gaming events will take place at different days and times than our regular monthly events. There may not be an event every month, but there could be multiple events in one month.

Byron Windhorst

results.description:
If you are brand new to the group, please read all the way to the bottom of this note. Thanks!

This is a good place to play games, get good food and drinks. Please patronize them. Game Knight Lounge is two blocks East of Legacy Hopspital at 3037 N. Williams Ave, cross street Monroe, walk South on Williams one business (on West side of street). Between Legacy and highway 99E on N. Williams Ave, cross street Monroe. There is a small parking lot which we can use on Saturdays. Also, street parking nearby. Get there early and you'll probably get street parking right in front. We'll start playing as soon as we can decide on a game. As others show up they can start another game.

Please note that there is a $4 cover charge paid to the restaurant to play games. I always patronize a place where I play games. (There were too many gamers who didn't purchase anything at all.)

CHAD our helper!

We have a helper who will be around to greet you especially on Meetup events when I can not be there. This will allow us to run the event nearly every Saturday. Of course, you can always go play games there on Saturday in that time spot, even if we don't announce an event.

Why the name Middleweight?

Historically, our group has played Middleweight games (less than 2 hours and easy rules that do not require detailed explanation for half the time it takes to play). With so much choice available at the Game Knight Lounge, feel free to agree with those present to play any game you wish.

SIGNING UP - PLEASE use the RSVP signup.

It is important to use the RSVP function. While you are welcome to come without doing a sign up, it helps the attendance. When people see that others have already signed up, they are more likely to also RSVP.. If you can’t make an event, PLEASE do the right thing (reverse the RSVP) so that one of the people on the Waiting List, has a chance to join the fun.

WAITLIST

Be patient if you are on the waitlist, Meetup will automatically notify you if a space becomes available. I've set it to 10 for the moment, but we could probably go up to 12 people in the back area. . I'll very likely expand the size of the event if we get into waitlist state. I really like playing games and welcome you to come play.

Byron Windhorst

results.description:
This month, we'll be jamming all day long.

Since this is a last-minute change, and I know that some people schedule time so they can make the afternoon jam, we'll keep that going from 1 'till 4.

So, if you want to jam in the afternoon, we'll be going from 1 'till 4 ...

... At which point, we'll break for a barbecue and potluck, for any who wish to join.

At some point, we'll start a fire, and begin setting up for an outdoor jam.

The fireside jam will run from 7 'till 10. (we'll stop promptly at 10, as we do not wish to annoy our neighbours)

We'll provide some basic condiments, a cheap charcoal grill, and some amazing potato salad. If anybody wishes to join in the barbecue, add something to the table if you can.

We'll roast some marshmallows and hot dogs around 8:30 or so.

So, 3 hours of jamming, 3 hours of barbecue, 3 hours of fireside jam.

We hope to see you there.

results.description:
Bring your four-legged companion and join us on a hike for some fun, exercise, and socialization!

***IMPORTANT***
Please do not use flexi leashes. FIXED leashes 6ft. or shorter are required. You will not be able to join the walk with a flexi leash.

$10 per dog, cash or Venmo.

VENMO OPTION:
Search for "The Balanced Dog" or[masked] to pay via card.

This group was started by our pack leader, Lyndsi. She found that during her training sessions with reactive dogs there weren't enough triggers within the neighborhood to get the dog the exposure, and repetition it needed to effectively reinforce positive social behaviors. She thought it would be great to have everyone come together to help each other!

Pack walk begins with a brief overview of basic desensitization techniques for anyone who needs support or is unsure of what techniques to use for their dog. During this time please maintain 6 ft. from dogs until bandanas are on and we understand each other’s needs. We accept that everyone comes from different backgrounds and different trainers and we encourage you to use techniques that work best for you and your dog. Lyndsi tries to bring new tips each week to ensure that each individual gets the knowledge they need. Please bring your treat pouches and the treats that your dog thinks are the best treats in the whole world!

We use a colored bandana system to create a safe environment for both owners and dogs. Bandanas are provided at the beginning of each walk.

Green= Dogs who are comfortable being greeted by people and other dogs.

Yellow= Dogs who are frightful of people, but comfortable meeting new dogs.

Red= Dogs who are reactive with people and other dogs— so we know to give space.

This is a journey for both you and your dog! We are here to support you so please push through your butterflies and join us, we promise you won’t regret it.

We strive to make this a safe, positive, fun, supportive and educational experience for everyone who comes.

Please message us if you have any questions or concerns and we look forward to seeing you at the next pack walk! Let your journey begin!

IMPORTANT!
AGAIN, No flexi leashes. NONE!

Refund Policy
This is a deeply discounted training class. Please give 24 hours notice if you would like to receive a refund or have your payment credited to another walk. This gives us time to fill your spot. Thank you!
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in the Visitor Center Parking Lot.

results.description:
During the summer, there are just so many events in Portland happening at one time, which one do you choose?

Mine of course!

The festival of the flowers takes place from June 1-12, and after the festival is over, from the 13th-15th, if something caught your eye, you can pay a little bit of money to bring it home with you and plant in your garden! There will be over 20,000 flowers for us to look at.

Every year, they place the flowers into specific locations to make a beautiful piece of art taking up the entire square.

We are meeting at 2pm. You will have until 2:30 to meet at the location I have specified and have uploaded a photo of in the photo section. Although if you late beyond 2:30, look for an Asian guy wearing a fedora. Otherwise, do not try and message me trying to ask me to help you find the group.

We are meeting by the statue of the man wearing a 3 piece suit, holding an umbrella, and pointing (technically he's hailing a cab).

If you're new to town, what better way than to step out into the square with a group of people who are there trying to make new friends! A very casual and light hearted event, you don't have to spend a dime to enjoy good company with people who want to talk to you!

Don't be shy and show off your outgoing personality!

Afterwards we will go somewhere close by for food and drinks. Don't ask because i have no clue where we're going.

This event is being cross promoted in 3 other groups: Portland new and not so new in town, 20/30s social drinkers club & Single professionals happy hour. The extra rsvps is reflecting the combine total of the 3 other groups.

results.description:
Hi Everyone, please join us for our weekly critique meeting. We are holding this every Saturday afternoon at First Christian Church. They have a great back room that can be closed off from everything and is nice and quiet! No more sound checks or pianos to deal with, so it's an ideal place for reading aloud.

We are using a read-aloud format. If you wish to have your work critiqued, please bring a short piece or chapter (about 2-3 double-spaced pages) to read out loud to the group. It can be any genre, including non-fiction or poetry, but we do ask that the material be R as we are in a public place and don't put age restrictions on our writers. You don't have to read - you can show up to listen and critique or just listen. We don't have set time limits on critiques - all we ask is that you be mindful of how many readers are reading after you so that everyone gets a chance to read. We unfortunately have to pay a monthly fee for the space so we will pass a hat. There's no cost to come but if you can spare a couple of dollars it will go to paying for the space.

Please RSVP so we have an accurate count so we know how many chairs to set up. Also please note: the building is locked so there will be someone at the Park Avenue entrance (the glass doors) between 1:30 - 2:00 to let you in. Don't be late! If you think you might be a bit late, please message Heather ahead of time so we can make arrangements.

We'll be playing the Tomb of Annihilation hardcover with related supplements.

ToA - chapter 2 (Pirates). In our last session, Adventurers captured a pirate captain. Now they attempt to chase down and bring the ship, Dragonfang, back to Port Nyanzaru.

2:30pm - 5:30pm

LOCATION: Glimpses of Wonder and Warfare -------------------------------------------
http://glimpsesofwonder.com/

No cost to play. You can support the store by simply making a snack or drink purchase. Or... buy some dice. You can never have enough dice. Also be sure to check out the nice selection of minis.

Glimpses of Wonder & Warfare
16771 SW 12th St Suite D, Sherwood, OR 97140

BRING -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

None of these are required, but you'll enjoy your experience more if you bring some or all of these along (or purchase at Glimpses).

• Some sort of tool for taking notes (crayon, notepad, tablet, etc).

• Your character sheet.

• Dice.

• A D&D Player's Handbook, fifth edition.

• A miniature for your character.

• A welcoming, open attitude and a creative mind.

ADVENTURERS LEAGUE LEGAL CHARACTERS ----------------------

What makes a character legal?

• Your character started at level 1 and gained experience at Adventurers League legal tables.

• Your character has been created according to the Adventurers League Players Guide rules: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B9SpxpRFdLmCeTE4alVIVjNBUXc/view

• Your Adventurers Log accurately reflects when and where you gained your magic items, experience, money, etc.

FRIENDLY LOCAL COMMUNITY --------------------------------------------

Follow League news, get updates about local conventions, participate in Adventures League surveys that will actually affect the League and the games you play in! Be part of this on our Adventurers League Oregon Facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/dndaloregon

results.description:
First Reformed is a 2017 American drama thriller film written and directed by Paul Schrader (Oscar nominated screenwriter of Taxi Driver and Raging Bull). It stars Ethan Hawke, Amanda Seyfried, and Cedric Kyles.

The film was screened in the main competition section of the 74th Venice International Film Festival to outstanding critical acclaim, particularly that of Ethan Hawke's performance, who is already generating a lot of awards season buzz even this early in the year.

Toller (Hawke) is a former military chaplain, struggling with the death of his son who he encouraged to enlist in the armed forces. He meets Mary (Amanda Seyfried), seeking counseling for her radical environmentalist husband which further challenges his beliefs.

In September 2017, A24 acquired distribution rights to the film. It is scheduled to be released in limited release on May 18, 2018. - wikipedia.org
results.name: A24 and Paul Schrader's - First Reformed

results.description:
Hello everyone! Let's gather again this Saturday at 6pm at Base Camp since the weather looks to be nice again. When we last met the topic was knowledge and certainty, but at my end of the table we circled the question of what makes up human rationality and what hard test cases are. Interesting stuff. Maybe Brandon could give a brief presentation of what his thoughts are on certainty? I'm not sure he got that far last time (philosophers love to talk!!). Also questions of the limits of science were discussed (not be me this time: Yeah!) although more as a practical matter. I'd like to explore more how natural science decreases our understanding of things even as it increases our power over them. Beware of power without understanding!

Hope to see you Saturday!

Hello Enlightened Souls,

With the full moon comes releasing. This is now the perfect time to not only let go, but for healing. Forgiveness is where it starts. Tonight Michael will help us with Divine Forgiveness, not only that in this life time, but also past lives to include everything and everyone across all time lines.
Come and listen to the Healing Sounds of Crystal Pyramids that reach every part of your being and cells, while providing harmonious balance within. These tones set the space and frequencies for the fully guided meditation. For those who are new, please know I personally guide all meditations while channeling Divine Energies. ( I am totally present and aware during energy channeling... It's Energy).

Preparing For The Meetup :
The Space is cleared with Holy Wood, Crystals are placed in the room, and all 7 Chakra Tibetan Singing Bowls are usually used before (or during) we start the meditation to bring us into a more synchronized balanced state. We often use the Healing Crystal Pyramids for Sound Healing as well. If you have never experienced Divine~Angel Healing before, then your in for a Unique Experience.

Please know this is a "SPIRITUAL" Group, and Not Religious. However the Group works well with religion too. There is no judgement here in our group. Whatever Universal Energy you believe in works here too. I simply channel the Highest Universal Energy into the room for everyone to experience. This is how I am of Service today. It's a beautiful and loving feeling for me!!

A bit about Sacred Wings:

I have been guided by the Angels, Universal Spirit, and Masters to be of service to those who would like "Their" help. Their presence is always here at my home. However, the energy of their powerful presence will meld with your higher self (Spirit) during the meditation and will infuse their healing love throughout your being and into your heart core.

Healing Meditations can help you in areas where there maybe lower vibration blocks; Hurt, forgiveness issues, relationship issues, fear, doubt, negativity, insecurity, and more. Angel Healing meditations will be unique to each individual and in raising your vibration/frequency. Your "Intent", to ask and receive healing, is Everything. You will also be practicing "The Art of Allowing" and "Co-Creating" in becoming "A Master of Your Own Creation".

We will share about our meditation experience afterwards (if you feel comfortable). This sharing helps us all in enlightening and connecting with each other as the Spiritual Beings that we are.

If you would like to invite more than 1 extra guest please try & let me know so I know how many will be attending in total for the group. Cost is $10.00 per person. If you have any questions and would like my phone number, just message me and I'll send it to you.

Additional Parking on the Side Street ~ 39th Ave. The back wooden gate will be open on the right side of side street. Follow the deck to the 2nd sliding door where you can enter the house. Love & Light, Alicia
