results.description:
***WHEN YOU RSVP YOU MUST PAY IMMEDIATELY WITH THE LINK BELOW OR ELSE YOUR RSVP WILL BE REMOVED. If you have any problems paying with the link, contact me. Spots are only held for those who pay in advance.***

Dining alfresco is a treat during the summer months in Portland and this dining experience will be like visiting the home of old Italian friends and eating in the style of an Italian family. While my husband was born in Genoa—moving to Portland as a boy—I'm a member of one of the oldest Italian families in the city of Portland.

Since childhood I've enjoyed cooking, and in a former life I was married to a chef and sommelier who is also a wine grower and winemaker. I learned a lot of kitchen tricks during that decade of my life to say the least!

This will be the third summer of my dinners. Several years ago I needed a creative way to pay for a sudden back surgery (Posterior Cervical Laminectomy) and I'm grateful these dinners helped me achieve that goal! Since then the garden and kitchen have both grown and changed quite a bit so I want to do this again.

I've continued to work in horticulture too and have branched out a bit into garden design.

So, what can you expect? It's 4 courses for $40. I use the best local ingredients—including garden-grown fare from our organic community garden plot—and I make virtually everything from scratch here in my home kitchen. Wine is not included. Bottles are typically brought and shared by guests and we've oddly never run out!

Payment is made in advance.
Seating is limited and reservations are held for those who pay in advance. If you RSVP, payment must be made as soon as possible.

Please use this link to pay through PayPal: http://paypal.me/LaDolceDinner/40

Our home is old, bohemian, and we're proudly part of Old Portland living at the base of Mt Tabor. I'm a garden blogger and writer (https://www.amateurbotannist.com), seed seller (Milton's Garden Menagerie (https://www.etsy.com/shop/MiltonsGrdnMenagerie), propagator at Cistus Nursery (http://www.cistus.com), and garden coach/designer.

Menu: Flavors of Sicily (menu is not yet set in stone)

Antipasti
—Homemade Pane di Carmelo (Semolina Bread) w/Sicilian Cheeses
—Caponata
—Arancini

Primi Piati
—Handmade Pasta with Pesto Trapanese

Verduri
—Broccoli con Olive Nere (Green Cauliflower with Black Olives)

Dolci
—Homemade Cannoli

I'm passionate about food, but I'm not a professional chef. I'm a home cook and am proud to be a home cook.

Ok, yes, I may have cooked cardoons on TV but I'm NO Giada. Garden Time: Cardoon Recipe (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6pqOv0VZPk4)
results.how_to_find_us: 12 SE 72nd Ave Portland, OR
results.name: Garden Dinner: Sicilian

results.description:
If you could design our future society, what spiritual values would you infuse it with?

Join a different kind of conversation — one that welcomes every perspective in a search for the truths that unite us. Let’s look deeper at our reality and reflect on the rapidly changing society and planet.

Please join us for a discussion on a spiritual perspective offered by the teachings of the Baha'i Faith on the future of global civilization and the role of respect, kindness, justice, action, and inter-personal and international understanding to realize world unity and peace. We will examine what the Baha'i Faith has to say about the coming together of all peoples, races and nations.

The event is free and open to all regardless of background or belief.

"So powerful is the light of unity that it can illuminate the whole earth." — Baha'i Teachings
results.name: What kind of society do you want to live in?

results.description:
• What we'll do
Join Portland Sound Sanctuary for our Extended Magical 2 hour sound healing event with an extended sound bath & cacao ceremony, where we powerfully open our hearts in intentional ceremony, and then dive deep into peace and relaxation with various musicians playing various sound healing instruments around/ over you. What are you ready to release? What are you ready to receive into your life? Come relax, rest deeply in the inner space and receive the high vibrations of the cacao elixir, guidance from your Higher Self, and get attuned with the sound healing frequencies.

In this popular Community Circle, we use the power of a sacred cacao elixir & sacred healing instruments--crystal signing & tibetan bowls, didgeridoo, drum, handpans, solfeggio tuning forks, gongs, chimes, bells, etc... as well as Invocation & Intention, some brief toning of sacred chants, to release anxiety, stress & negativity, and to invoke higher wisdom, healing, empowerment & well-being, where we can expand into the abundantly wise, blissful energies of our inner LIGHT, our True Selves.

First in ceremony we create a sacred space by calling in the 7 directions, the ancestors, our guides on the etheric planes, etc... set the intention for clearing, healing and embodying our highest Selves then partake in opening our hearts with the ceremonial grade cacao from a cacao shaman in Guatemala... then immersing ourselves in powerful sound healing frequencies... going into DEEP RELAXATION at a cellular level... melting into healing and Bliss.

Led by Mikaela Jones in cacao intention, breath and toning exercises, on crystal & tibetan bowls/tuning forks/shamanic drum/chimes, and accompanied by Viola Rose on didge, shamanic drum, gong, handpans/Voice & guided meditation, etc, as well as other Sound Alchemists on tibetan bowls, etc, etc... We will begin with an intentional cacao ceremony (cacao is optional), leading into some chanting to further open the heart and then over an hour long sound bath where you will be lying down and receiving the various sound healing instruments played over you to further deepen your healing and expand into A STATE OF BLISS. People have reported amazing transformations... So be open for miracles...

For those who would like to enhance their experience with sacred plant medicine, we will be serving a home-made hot cacao elixir made with a delicious ceremonial-grade organic raw cacao in an organic coconut-milk base for $5. The cacao elixir will help open your heart gently and powerfully. This plant Deva helps us more deeply connect to our Inner Truth of love, bliss, and peace. Please be advised: if you have issues with digestion or are sensitive to caffeine, it is recommended that you only drink a little bit the first time, and build up over time if you like. you can just have a few sips and save for later too.

Visit our website: http://www.portlandsoundsanctuary.com/
and the facebook event: https://www.facebook.com/events/1699381453482995

• What to bring
Exchange:
$25-30 sliding scale. Cash only.

• Important to know
Please list yourself as going if you'd like to come. Mikaela will send out private messages to see if you'd like to partake in the optional cacao elixir so that she makes sure to make enough for everybody.
When:
7-9. Doors OPEN at 6:45. Please arrive then to have time to get your cacao and get settled into your cozy nests.

Optional Cacao Elixir: $5. Cash only.
Where: Parking lot and plenty of parking on Killingsworth and 20th Ave.

results.description:
It's that time of year again! Parade season! One of portlands largest parade, the starlight parade is probably my favorite.

I'm also asking for the people going if they can generously bring some kind of fruit or vegetables to share. Up don't have to bring a bunch but for example like 3-4 apples, oranges, bananas, grapes strawberries, baby carrots, couple of crowns of broccoli, pineapple plums cherry tomatoes.

Due to a members request, we will allow chocolate and cheese.

I will have a knife, cutting board and trays to set the food in as well as ranch. Please no junk food.
I would like to have everyone share something we won't feel so guilty about eating.

Floats with lights on them make this experience a very fun and family friendly event so if you have a little one, bring them too!

We're going to do it like we did it last year right in front of the rialto. When I say in front, I mean literally 5 feet in front of the entrance. People got lost last year so let me make it very specific. Head towards the entrance. Turn 180 degrees with the door to your back. The people directly in front of you close to the curb and possibly on to the street is where we will be at.

The parade doesn't start until 8:30. Please don't be late or you may not even be able to walk through the crowds of people. Over 325,000 people attend this event.

If you plan on socializing, I would recommend showing up early and chat while we wait. As soon as its parade time it's hard to hear each other.

I also need help from people who feel like drinking to show up around the time I posted. Rialto puts benches outside out front where you can legally sit and drink and watch the parade. I want to take over as many tables as we can.

You can also bring a chair or a small blanket to place on the ground to sit on. That or an old coat you can put on the curb and sit on.

Parking? Good luck. Even if you find a spot, getting out is bumper to bumper. I've seen people park in those parking structures and they get grid locked. Imagine over 300,000 people filling the streets going every which way to get home.

The jams usually happen from pedestrians crossing in the crosswalk and the drivers unable to maneuver. If you do park, park as far away as you can humanly walk from. Trust me.

That or do what I do. Take transit. Park at a transit station and take it in. It's fast and efficient.

This event is being cross promoted in 3 other groups: People in the city, 20/30s social drinkers club & Single professionals happy hour. The extra rsvps is reflecting the combine total of the 3 other groups.
results.name: Starlight parade 2018!

Ed Bennett - Bass, Tim Willcox - tenor saxophone, Charlie Porter - trumpet, Dan Gaynor - Piano, and Tim Rap - Drums!

Ed Bennett has long been considered one of the West Coast's premiere string bass players. Since his arrival in 1990, Ed has become a mainstay in the Portland jazz community.

The fresh sounds of Bennett’s original compositions are be-bop influenced, but unique with twists in their harmonic progressions and unusual forms.

The quintet will be playing Ed's original compositions along with works by Horace Silver, Miles Davis, and Kent Glenn!

Please bring something small to share with others (snacks, nuts, wine, etc.). This is a potluck jazz party and concert.

Portland, OR 97215

This is an all-ages, all-are-welcome, community dance event with live music and caller. There are always new folks in attendance as well as experienced dancers who will be happy to show you the ropes. Please RSVP so folks who are shy about showing up alone will know they are among friends! Tonight’s contra dance features caller David Kaynor from Massachusetts and local band The Stage Crew (Sue Songer, Lanny Martin, Lori Shaffer).

As always there will be a lesson for newcomers at 7:30 and the dancing will start at 8 pm. At around 9:30, we’ll have a waltz, then a break, then more dancing until we end at 11 with a final waltz. Afterwards, we’ll adjourn to the Hillsdale Pub (1505 SW Sunset Blvd) for socializing with friends old and new. It’s fine to come by yourself, as you’ll find plenty of partners on the dance floor! Contra dancing is aerobic so dress accordingly and wear comfortable shoes preferably with suede or leather soles (or you can wear any kind of shoes with a sock pulled over them!)

Cost: $6 for students/seniors, $8 general admission. Please bring cash or check.

results.description:
By popular demand, we're headed back to Hazel Dell Lanes for their late-night cosmic bowling event. Open Friday and Saturday nights, Thunder Alley combines all the fun of ten-pin bowling with all the excitement of a black light rave (minus the furry leg warmers and fishnet tank tops, thankfully). Our last experience here was an incredibly fun time, and I for one am pumped for the return trip. If you only attend one after-dark bowling Meetup event in the Vancouver area this week, make it this one.

SCHEDULE:

8:00 PM - Arrive at the Cedar Room Lounge (located inside Hazel Dell Lanes) to socialize, eat, have a drink, and/or sing some karaoke.

9:30 PM - Thunder Alley opens and bowling begins! Cost is $14 per person, which includes shoe rental and unlimited bowling until 12:30.

12:30 AM - Thunder Alley concludes. If enough folks are up for it, we'll head somewhere else for even more good times. Saturday night only happens once a week, after all.

Now able to walk, Grey finds that he also has superhuman strength and agility -- skills he uses to seek revenge against the thugs who destroyed his life.

results.description:
The Neahkahnie Mountain peak overlooks the magnificent crescent-shaped beach of Manzanita, over 1600 feet below. The Tillamook tribe believed their most powerful god resided at this peak. Neahkahnie translates into Ne ("place of") Ekahnie ("supreme deity").

Soon after starting the hike, you'll have ocean views. Then, it's off into beautiful forested area until we reach the peak. The hike is around 6 miles roundtrip. We won't be taking the long loop because we need to get back for those epic eats I promised you.

After looking down on the beach in Manzanita, we're going to drive into that little city and have lunch at Bread and Ocean. They offer quiche, frittatas, polentas, sandwiches, soups, and salads. And then there's the tall dessert case. The desserts vary, but you may come across an orange walnut roll, cinnamon roll, a macaroon covered in chocolate and almonds, and several sweet and gooey bars that will have you salivating.

We'll meet at Foothills Park and carpool from there. I can take a few people in my car. If anyone will volunteer to drive additional vehicles, if needed, please comment below. For non-drivers, please provide your driver with $5 for gas/transportation costs. I'm guessing that this trip will last 7 1/2 hours. We depart shortly after the meet time, so please be on time.

So, come out and your whole life will change for the better. Your parents will be more proud of you than they already are. Your dog will look at you more adoringly. You'll be able to live in Portland rent free. That guy you've wanted to ask you out will finally ask you out. You won't have to shower for weeks and will still smell great. You'll inherit a million dollars. Okay, I'm not promising any of that will happen, but wouldn't it be great if it did?

Driver directions to trailhead:
http://www.oregonhikers.org/field_guide/North_Neahkahnie_Mountain_Trailhead
results.how_to_find_us: Meet us at the picnic table in Foothills Park.
results.name: Neahkahnie Mountain & Bread and Ocean

results.description:
PLEASE READ THE FULL DESCRIPTION BELOW!!!

I discovered this place while working on a soon-to-be-published map of it for OSU, and was pleasantly surprised at how nice it was...sort of Corvallis' answer to Portland's Forest Park. Expect about 12-13 miles (give or take) of trail hiking, mostly through forest but with some meadows & open spaces thrown in, with maybe 1500 feet of total elevation gain (I'm still deciding which trails to do). Some of it will be new to me too. Should be a good day out, discovering an area I'm betting few of us even knew existed!

THE OUTING

Rating: Moderate...all on maintained trails. None of the individual trails is more than 3.5 miles long, so we'll be tying a few of them together and maybe doing a short drive between them (or maybe even a car shuttle).

Elevation gain: Unknown, but I'm anticipating maybe 1500 feet of total elevation gain.

Hike distance: roughly 12-13 miles

Hiking time: 5 hours, give or take

http://cf.forestry.oregonstate.edu/mcdonald-forest-trails
(no, these are not my maps!)

We'll meet at Barbur Blvd Park & Ride at 830am and carpool to the trailhead, roughly 90 mins away (75 miles).

We should be hiking by 1030am, and finished by late afternoon. I plan to stop for food and drink in either Corvallis or Albany on the return to Portland. I'd anticipate being back in Portland no later than 8pm, but as always I can't guarantee it. If you really need to be back by a specific time, please don't sign up!

MORE DETAILS (please read them!)

My hiking style: I'm a pretty tireless hiker, but I do pause for photos, views, and snack breaks. I generally focus on enjoying the surroundings rather than reaching the 'finish line' at an aggressive pace. I like keeping the group somewhat together on the trail and not leaving anyone behind. Most of all, I want it to be an enjoyable day out for everyone!

Total driving distance: roughly 170 miles round-trip.

Costs: Suggested $15 per person to driver for gas (may vary depending on each car's gas mileage).

What to bring: a positive attitude and a sense of adventure, hiking shoes (trail runners are fine for this outing), sunscreen, at least 2 liters of water, snacks (and lunch) for the trail, camera, cash for your driver. Dress in layers (bring a waterproof layer just in case), and leave the cotton at home. I always strongly encourage you to have the 'ten essentials' along (see The Fine Print below), regardless of the difficulty of the hike.

Sorry, no dogs...

* The 'ten essentials' to always have in your pack generally include: Map/compass (and advance understanding of where you're going!), sun protection, extra clothes, extra food, extra water, headlamp/flashlight (and spare batteries), first aid kit, matches/firestarter, knife/tools, and a whistle if you need to signal for help. You should always be prepared in case you get separated from the rest of the group and/or have to spend a night on your own in the wilderness.

* As a Meetup organizer, I'm an unpaid volunteer. While I always try to ensure a safe and enjoyable outing for everyone, by signing up for this event you assume full responsibility for your own health, safety, and well-being for its entire duration, including while traveling to and from both the meeting place and destination.

results.name: Hiking in McDonald Research Forest (Corvallis)

results.description:
Let's spend the late morning sun(?) talking about Agile-inspired and other topics that shake loose from our minds.

We'll spend the first few minutes gathering discussion ideas, then roll right into the smooth easy cadence of the lively chatter.

New to Lean Coffee? It's a great way to have real, focused dialogue and we often discuss matters of agile, lean and such - but anything goes. As far as the mechanics, here's the template:

Step 1: Everybody writes down proposed topics on stickies, placing them in the center of the table. Take as much time as needed, but typically takes only 3-5 minutes (or whenever coffee is ready).

Step 2: Each topic is briefly described by its writer to get a flavour for the subject (15-30 seconds typically per sticky).

Step 3: Each person gets a small number of votes which they indicate by marking the voted-for sticky with their sharpie (all votes on one, one across many, however you feel).

Step 4: The top stickies are placed in the ToDo column, ordered by the stickies with the most votes at the top.

Step 5: Each of these stickies are discussed for 5 minutes, most votes first. The facilitator takes a quick "Cesar" (thumbs up/down) vote at the five-minute timer, and she moves on for three more minutes if the discussion still has majority interest. When complete, move the sticky over to the Done column. Rinse and repeat.

Step 6: wrap-up thoughts at the end - what one idea or person did you most enjoy, then break for home/drinks/cover.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the pile of stickies and pens
results.name: High Church of Lean Coffee: Portland perfection edition

results.description:
For this discussion we'll take advantage of two articles. The 1st is a review of David Reich’s career work with ancient human DNA, from the New York Times’ ‘Profiles in Science’ posted in March a week before the publication of his new book, “Who We Are and How We Got Here”. The 2nd is an opinion piece by Reich himself discussing the scientific and social implications, and potential misuses, of this burgeoning field.

“David Reich Unearths Human History Etched in Bone”
https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/20/science/david-reich-human-migrations.html

“How Genetics Is Changing Our Understanding of ‘Race’”
https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/23/opinion/sunday/genetics-race.html

“I am worried that well-meaning people who deny the possibility of substantial biological differences among human populations are digging themselves into an indefensible position, one that will not survive the onslaught of science. I am also worried that whatever discoveries are made — and we truly have no idea yet what they will be — will be cited as “scientific proof” that racist prejudices and agendas have been correct all along, and that those well-meaning people will not understand the science well enough to push back against these claims.
This is why it is important, even urgent, that we develop a candid and scientifically up-to-date way of discussing any such differences, instead of sticking our heads in the sand and being caught unprepared when they are found.” –David Reich

If you're interested, here are two brief reviews that include some of the book's major points about specific populations:

https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/mar/29/who-we-are-how-got-here-david-reich-ancient-dna-review

https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/20/books/review/david-reich-who-we-are-how-we-got-here.html

~Michael
results.name: Human Population Genetics: “Who We Are and How We Got Here”

WE WILL MAKE EVERY ATTEMPT TO LEAVE ON TIME so please make sure and give yourself some extra time to get there and prepare for the ride.

Traffic: A lot of this is on bike paths with no cars. Some city and country roads, so be comfortable riding with and without shoulders and with fast traffic but a lot of this ride is on country rural roads with good visibility.

Ride Category: Intermediate: 15-30 miles / 12 -14 mph. 3% grade max

https://ridewithgps.com/routes/12106744

Restrooms: (Availability and location) At Start/finish at Fred Meyers. We may be able to find one on route too.

Parking: Good, in parking lot, please park onthe south end near/past the bottle return.

Ride Coordinator / Event Host: Laura Gillilan,[masked]. Text preferred over calls if able. Weather Policy: Cancellations will be posted 3 hours before ride time. We will ride in very light rain and winds, if it looks like a miserable day, will cancel but the plan is to ride. We will not ride in heavy rain, hard winds, thunder, ice, or snow.

CycleManiacs is a non-professional meet-up group of cycling enthusiasts intended to share a social, safe, and fun group riding experience with others. Mandatory for all riders: Helmets must be worn at all times while riding. This is a requirement and not a request.

Please review each ride and determine which is the appropriate for your skill level. If any questions or suggestions, you are always welcome to message me through the site and ask. Always bring plenty of water, snacks for energy. Bring a flat repair kit, including a spare tube tool kit and pump and be prepared to change your own tire but know we will always help you if needed. Obey traffic laws. Be a good steward of your cycling community. Working lights are mandatory for all evening and night rides.

No Earbuds. No exceptions.

Make sure your bike is in good mechanical condition to start the ride.

Nobody gets left behind. No one will be dropped from the ride. Our goal is we all get back to the start point safe and sound.

We do not use the term “all clear” when crossing intersections.

Conditions can change quickly. When “Car Back” is called, it means single file. These and other terms will be discussed at rides start. Each rider is responsible for his or her own safety and is expected to ride in a safe group riding manner, which does not create a danger to others.

Manage your RSVP’s

The number of riders for each ride are limited by the event host, and based on the experience of the participants, the course, and conditions. If you sign up for the ride, and your schedule changes, you must change your RSVP to NO. This will allow riders on the waiting list to fill the vacancy and enjoy the ride. Please don’t wait till the last minute. We will track no shows. Those who repeatedly “no show” may be moved to the bottom of the wait list.

RSVP’s cannot include a “plus one” or guest. Every participant must be a member of CycleManiacs, and thereby in acceptance of the release and waiver of liability terms.

RELEASE AND WAIVER OF LIABILITY

By participating in any posted event, you're taking responsibility for your own safety. Your RSVP signifies that you agree to the following.

Organizers, event hosts and other participants will not be held responsible for any individual at any event. Each rider rides at their own risk and is solely responsible for any damage to their equipment or themselves. Your personal safety depends on your own experience and judgment. By joining as a member you are agreeing that you are waiving any and all legal or civil rights for responsibility to the organizer, co-organizer, assistant organizers, event host and any other members within the group.

About Rood Bridge Park
https://www.hillsboro-oregon.gov/departments/parks-recreation/our-parks/rood-bridge-park
Rood Bridge Park is located in southeast Hillsboro. The park encompasses 60 acres on the north bank of the Tualatin River at its confluence with Rock Creek. It is the city’s largest park, and contains tennis courts, a playground, a meeting facility, trails, a canoe launch, and a rhododendron garden among other beautiful features.

General Park Rules and Regulations
- Please clean the area following event

- No staples, tacks, tape or nails are allowed to attach tablecloths, decorations, signs, etc. to picnic tables, shelters or trees

- Alcoholic beverages are not permitted. This law is strictly enforced

- Use of any tobacco products or vaping is not permitted. This law is strictly enforced

- Park is closed dusk to dawn

- Motorized vehicles are prohibited except in parking areas

- Dogs must be on leash and excrement must be removed from the park

- There is no reserved parking. Parking is first come, first served

out·li·er: Noun

“a person or thing situated away or detached from the main body or system”

As life travelers, in body and spirit, we all have deeply personal burdens and struggles that we carry. Some of our burdens are named ones: depression, anxiety, loss, addiction, shame, religious guilt, codependency, physical illness, etc….. Some of our pains are unnamed. What they all seem to have in common, however, is that they make us feel like we don’t belong, tearing us away from the present moment and the 'now'.

Eventually, we seem to figure out somewhere along the journey that it is better to embrace openness and vulnerability in dealing with these challenges, rather than trod a path of hiddenness and repression. Though this road is not necessarily easy, its travelers slowly begin to feel and claim their purpose and connectedness………

The Outlier Gang is a meetup that allows us to safely share our stories about how we deal with named or unnamed struggles, what tools, guides or practices have helped us along our journeys, and how to explore potential creative ways that help turn any seeming weaknesses into strengths for us and others…………

The only agenda is to listen, share, and honor each story, with some good tea or coffee............
results.how_to_find_us: Just look for a few lovable misfits........
results.name: The Outlier Gang: a meetup to share stories that matter

Come and find out what happens when your brain waves switch to Theta state. This is your path to the spiritual dimension; direct contact with non-ordinary reality and your spirit guides. This is the path to spiritual wellness, insight, and the guidance you may be looking for. Sara will lead you through at least three sessions of Shamanic Journey Meditation accompanied by live rhythmic drumming with the intent to connect to your spirit-guide/power-animal. Learn how this powerful connection can transform your life and your world view. Bring what you need to lie comfortably on the floor, an eye covering, something to write with, and paper or a journal to write your Journey experiences on. This class is for beginners and for experienced Journeyers alike! For the past 18 years Sara Violante has been practicing Journey Meditation and Healing for herself and for others. She is Formally trained in Shamanic Healing and Vision Quest and is a certified Spiritual Healer and Reiki Master. SaraViolante.com

results.description:
Hello Forest bathers. Welcome to Shinrin- yoku. Forest bathing is the practice of emerging yourself into the forest and allowing nature to enter your body. All five senses will will be focused on individually throughout the course of this journey.

We will start with some light breathing to help us clear our mind from outside influences and instead, be present. It is recommended that electronic devices be left in vehicles or put on silent mode. Light conversation is encouraged but please respect other bathers.

After some light breathing, and one or two standing yoga poses, we’ll begin our journey. Throughout our walk I may pause the group so that we may all focus on one of the five senses. It is purposeful to close our eyes during these pauses, breathing and then re-Opening our eyes.
results.name: Forest bathing

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
